Mr. Speaker, this morning I have 35 petitions from Canadians in nearly every province, from British Columbia to Newfoundland.
These petitioners urge the government and especially the Parliament of Canada to restore the Court Challenges Program which gives all Canadians equal access to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, regardless of their financial resources.
These people deplore the government's decision to end this important program which, as we know, helped Canadians assert their language rights and equality rights and have them interpreted by the courts.
These many Canadian petitioners ask this House to make a positive decision in this regard and reinstate the program.

Mr. Speaker, I have another petition signed by Canadians who support the following statement: In the hope that all Canadians will give their elders the necessary support to live as independently as possible, the federal government has the primary responsibility to ensure that old age pensions are adequate.
Therefore, the petitioners ask the House of Commons to urge the government to make sure that Canada's old age pensions are high enough to meet the essential needs of Canadian seniors.

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour and duty to present petitions from my constituents in Whitehorse and Pelly Crossing, Yukon, who are very concerned about this government's actions which have very much undermined rural life in Canada.
They state in this petition that whereas recent actions of the government have been a direct attack on the rural
way of life including cuts to VIA Rail service, abandoning rail lines and neglecting fisheries, forestry and agriculture and the erosion of rural postal services, particularly by the closure of small rural post offices, whereas post offices are the backbone of many of our rural communities, these petitioners pray and call upon the Parliament of Canada to support Canada's rural way of life, to support the maintenance of rural post offices and postal services and to reject the agenda of closures and cutbacks and make sure that rural Canadians can be truly Canadians from coast to coast to coast.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the following questions will be answered today: Nos. 295, 296, 297 and 298.

With respect to the Human Rights, Women's Equality and Social Affairs Division of the Department of External Affairs, is its first mission to promote the integration of human rights and women's equality into all aspects of Canadian foreign policy and, if so, (a) how is this promoted through other ministries whose policies and programs are part of Canadian foreign policy such as trade, immigration (refugee determination) and aid (b) what specific functions are undertaken by staff to ensure the inclusion of human rights and women's equality into foreign policy (c) how is information gathered and who or what groups are consulted to gather information (d) how does it support or influence other federal departments to implement international human rights instruments?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara Jean McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
A prime focus of the Human Rights Women's Equality and Social Affairs Division, IMH, is to

June 23, 1992
Routine Proceedings
promote the progressive integration of human rights and women's equality into Canada's foreign policy.
The Department of External Affairs, both IMH and other divisions, works in close consultation with other ministries whose policies and programs impact on Canadian foreign policy. This is particularly true with regard to CIDA on any matter involving official development assistance and multiculturalism, citizenship and justice on implementation of international protocols. It should be noted that trade issues are handled within the department itself. The division works with CIDA to offer a joint course in human rights and democratic development for officers in both departments. The course addressed, inter alia, trade and immigration issues. The division also takes the lead on interdepartmental meetings dealing with multilateral human rights issues involving the Departments of Multiculturalism and Citizenship, Indian and Northern Affairs, CIDA, Justice, Status of Women Canada, Labour and the Canadian Human Rights Commission.
Specific functions undertaken by IMH staff to ensure the inclusion of human rights into foreign policy include:
Working closely with other divisions responsible for specific regions to ensure that Canadian concerns about human rights and women's equality concerns are, as appropriate, raised with foreign governments. The division is consulted on all military export permits to sensitive areas, relevant policy memoranda to portfolio ministers, ministerial briefing material, statements and news releases.
Requesting and co-ordinating the preparation of annual reports on human rights in various countries, monitoring these and ongoing reports from embassies, NGOs, media and other sources.
Working with Canada's multilateral missions and other external affairs divisions to ensure that human rights and women's equality are managed appropriately at the UN, the OAS, the Commonwealth, la Francophonie, and the CSCE.
Preparing briefs and instructions for the Canadian delegation to the UN Commission on Human Rights, the Third Committee of the UN General Assembly, and the Social Committee of the UN Economic and Social
Council. Staff may also serve on these delegations as advisors.
Organizing consultations with non-governmental organizations in the human rights field. These consultations are also attended by representatives of geographic divisions. Individual meetings with Canadian and foreign NGOs are organized on request during the year.
Information on human rights in various countries is gathered from a variety of sources, the main ones being Canadian posts abroad, the United Nations, and nongovernmental organizations. In addition to preparing annual reports Canadian posts abroad keep the department up to date on any developments affecting the human rights situation.
IMH is in regular contact with Canadian and international non-governmental organizations in the field of human rights, and receives numerous United Nations documents and NGO publications, including all of Amnesty International's country and thematic reports. The division ensures that these are given appropriate distribution to concerned decisjon-makers. The division also has access to media monitoring services available in EAITC.
The division consults on an ongoing basis with other departments regarding the implementation of international human rights instruments, primarily Multiculturalism and Citizenship Canada, which has a lead role in that area, the Department of Justice, the Department of Indian and Northern Affairs, Status of Women Canada, et cetera. The division reviews drafts of Canada's reports under the international instruments for coherence and consistency. Over-all responsibility for the preparation of these reports lies with the Department of Multiculturalism and Citizenship and other sectoral departments assume responsibilities for the preparation of the relevant federal sections. The division is also responsible for ensuring that the reports are prepared and sent to the UN or OAS on time and as required, may assist in their presentation and defence before the relevant treaty bodies.
The division also ensures that UN and NGO documents, telegrams from posts and other relevant material is circulated to the appropriate officials in the domestic departments to keep them informed of international developments in the human rights field.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara Jean McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
A key objective of the Human Rights, Women's Equality and Social Affairs Division, as cited in the division's mission statement, is "to convey to Canadians the department's deep and abiding interest in promoting Canadian values of human rights and social justice." In conjunction with other divisions, such as those directly concerned with public communications, IMH works to ensure that the Canadian public is aware of Canada's efforts to promote human rights at the international level. The division's specific activities in this regard include:
Informing non-governmental organizations in the field of human rights of Canadian initiatives and actions. This is done both through regular consultations between the department and NGOs, and through the mailing of reports, speeches and other relevant information to a list of some 150 non-governmental organizations.
Responding to correspondence and telephone inquiries from the public on what Canada is doing to promote human rights internationally.
Drafting and presenting speeches to Canadian audiences, including NGOs, universities, et cetera, and preparing or contributing to public statements on international human rights issues by the Secretary of State for External Affairs, the Minister for External Relations and other ministers.
Providing up-to-date information and briefings to the EAITC media relations office and ministerial spokespersons.
Ensuring that Canadian media representatives covering international fora receive copies of Canadian statements and are aware of Canadian initiatives.

The public is kept informed of the department's policies and actions in the area of human rights in the following ways:
Ongoing consultation with non-governmental organizations in the field of human rights and organizations representing aboriginal peoples.
A three-day consultation prior to the annual session of the UN Commission on Human Rights.
Ongoing contact between IMH officers and NGO representatives. These can range from regular telephone conversations to meetings with specific NGOs. IMH has also facilitated bilateral meetings between major human rights NGOs and the Secretary of State for External Affairs and other authorities.
Reporting on Canadian and UN actions through the circulation of statements, reports and documents, for example, the division prepares a detailed report following the annual session of the Commission on Human Rights outlining the outcome of the commission and Canada's role. This report is sent to approximately 150 non-governmental organizations in the field of human rights. This year, the division also mailed out reports of the January consultations with NGOs and aboriginal organizations, as well as a report on the recent Second Preparatory Committee for the World Conference on Human Rights.
Preparing or contributing to ministerial correspondence, statements and briefing material for meetings with parliamentarians or Canadian organizations. IMH regularly prepares responses to public inquiries on the department's policies and activities in the areas of international human rights, women's equality and social

Motion No. 5.
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 5 by striking out line 17 at page 3 and substituting the following therefor:
"lished by the Treasury Board or by the Commission for purposes of section 5.2, to improve".
Motion No. 7.
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 5 by adding immediately after line 25 at page 3 the following:
"5.2(1) In exercising or performing any of its powers, functions or duties under this Act, the Commission shall act in such manner as is likely to advance the implementation of employment equity in the public service and may, for this purpose, establish policies and programs to improve employment and career opportunities for designated groups in the Public Service, including women, aboriginal peoples, persons with disabilities and persons who are, because of their race or colour, in a visible minority in Canada, and to correct the conditions of disadvantage experienced by such groups in their employment.

June 23, 1992

(2)	For purposes of subsection (1), the Commission shall, in consultation with the Treasury Board and the bargaining agents representing persons employed in the Public Service, advance the implementation of employment equity by:
(a)	identifying and eliminating each of the employment practices of the Commission not otherwise authorized by law, that results in employment barriers against persons in designated groups; and
(b)	instituting such positive policies and practices and making such reasonable accommodation as will enable the employer to ensure that persons in designated groups achieve a degree of representation in the various positions of employment within the Public Service that is at least proportionate to their representation
(i)	in the work force, or
(ii)	in those segments of the work force that are identifiable by qualification, eligibility or geography and from which the Public Service may reasonably be expected to draw or promote employees.
(3)	The Commission shall, in respect of each fiscal year, prepare a plan setting out
(a)	the goals that it intends to achieve in advancing the implementation of employment equity in the year or years to which the plan relates; and
(b)	the timetable for the implementation of those goals.
(4)	The Commission shall include in its annual report laid before Parliament the number of applicants for employment in the Public Service, the number of persons recruited, referred, and appointed by the Commission or within its jurisdiction and the number of such persons falling within designated groups."
She said: Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to present these two motions which are intended to complete the issue of employment equity in the Public Service and to comment at this time favourably on the words of Senator Pat Carney who in a previous incarnation asked: "Where are the women?".

Of course, the basic principle in the Public Service with hiring, promotions, recruiting and the merit principle is that someone can have a job and advance according to his or her ability.
This has worked well for the past 70 years, if you are a white man. If you are a woman or disabled or native or have a different skin colour, the merit principle has not worked. Of course, half the employees in the Public Service are women, but less than 15 per cent of the other
public servants are women. The same principles apply if you are not white or are disabled or a native.
The legislative committee made progress on this question. The committee agreed to ensure that Treasury Board, as the employer of public servants, must respect employment equity and have programs for ensuring equal opportunity in promotions and hiring, even for women, native people, coloured people and the disabled. The Public Service is a different kind of employer from the private sector. We have an organization called the Public Service Commission which has a very specific and special role to play in ensuring employment and advancement based on ability within the public service.

This principle of merit that the best qualified person gets the job has worked reasonably well for 70 years if you are a man and if you are white. The figures are absolutely clear that if you do not fit those two qualifications you have not been judged on merit.
We only need to look at the figures for this year for the Public Service Commission. Even in this year, with the voluntary policy of employment equity, although half of the employees in the Public Service are women, less than 15 per cent of the managers are women. Even this year over 75 per cent of the appointments, promotions and moves within the management category were men. If one happens to have skin that is not white it is even worse; representation in the management category is abysmal. Aboriginal Canadians or persons with a disability simply do not count and the glass ceiling is there throughout the Public Service.
It is unacceptable that more than two years after the task force on barriers to women in the Public Service reported to this House there has not been more progress, and that even these steps to achieve progress are not being taken.
The merit principle is one of the fundamental issues at stake in this bill. It is based on your ability to do the job, not who your friends are or how well your boss likes you. The merit principle should be the basis on which people
June 23, 1992

Government Orders
are either hired or promoted or, for that matter, demoted or fired in the Public Service.
We were successful in committee and I thank the members of the committee and the managers who assisted in drafting a change. We have had an Employment Equity Act in this country that applies to the private sector for over five years. It has never applied to the public sector. In committee we were able to move an amendment and work with members of the committee and senior managers to finally have the same requirements that apply to private sector employers apply to the public sector.
However, the job is only half done because those requirements apply to the Treasury Board as employer but they do not apply to the Public Service Commission. The Public Service Commission is the defender of the merit principle. Its whole function is to ensure that only merit applies and that the shape of your body or the colour of your skin does not determine whether you get hired or promoted in the Public Service.
The purpose of Motions Nos. 5 and 7 is to quite simply complete the work we did in committee to ensure that the Public Service Commission, as the employment agency of the Government of Canada, is bound by the same requirements to respect employment equity which the government has now accepted will apply to the employer.
The commission, for reasons totally mysterious to me, is resisting this. It says: "Well, we already do it". Yes, it does but it does it quite imperfectly. For instance 12 per cent of applicants last year in the Public Service were people of colour but only 5 per cent of hirings were people of colour. Why? What is being done to address that?
The Public Service Commission is the agent of Parliament that ensures that only ability to do the job counts in hirings, promotions, training or opportunities to progress in the Public Service.
If the Treasury Board has a legal obligation, which it will have under this bill, to be an equal opportunity employer then the commission, as its hiring agent and as the instrument of this Parliament to ensure fairness and transparency in the hiring process in the Public Service, must have that same obligation.
We will come to other amendments where the commission has resisted changes to how it carries out its work. I do not believe on this important issue that the commission can have the discretion to decide whether it wants to act in a manner consistent with employment equity or not.
It is up to us as Parliament, the commission is our agent, to provide a very clear legal direction that this Public Service is going to be fair and equal for everybody and to make it accountable to this Parliament and not leave it to the discretion of three appointed commissioners to decide whether they do or do not think that people of colour, women, aboriginals, and disabled persons should have equal opportunities in the Public Service.
I look forward to hearing the government respond to these amendments and explain why it does not think they are acceptable, if it does not.

Mr. Speaker, I want to take this opportunity to thank our colleague from Ottawa West and all members of the committee that examined this bill and who are proposing this particular amendment.
I want to thank them because since 1985 we have worked very hard to look at employment equity as a basic and fundamental principle in law. We have worked to ensure that section 15, which is the non-discrimination section of our Canadian charter, be not only written on paper but be applied in actual fact in the course of the life of this country, for the citizens in the working world and in general.
When my colleague came and told me that they had moved this amendment which would have an implication for Treasury Board and would apply the whole principle of employment equity to Treasury Board I was absolutely delighted. I congratulate her once again in public because that has been the most difficult group to move.
We wrote a landmark report on the application of employment equity and on the application of section 15 of the charter but when the government introduced the Employment Equity Act it managed to leave itself outside of the act and apply it to the private sector. Instead of being the role model that it should have been it left itself untouched by the application of non-discrimination in the work force.
The answer at that time was: "Well, we do it". If we do it then it must be applied in law and perceived to be just.

June 23, 1992
Government Orders
It must be just and in the laws of the land. I am delighted that this will come to be within the purview of this law.
I would really like to know how the government can step aside from one's responsibility when it accepts the principle that it has a responsibility for the employment of visible minorities, women, aboriginal people, handicapped people, and those who have been perceived to be the weak and the underemployed in our society.
The government is now going to accept its responsibility that it should have in the first place, through the Treasury Board, but it is not going to apply to the hiring agent that is going to do the job for the government, the Public Service Commission. That makes absolutely no sense.
It is like putting together a lovely picture but forgetting to put a proper base to hold the stand, or building a statue with no stand to hold it so it will not fall down.
This is a very key amendment, as are the other amendments that are being discussed. If we want to respect this country that we want to keep unified and in which we want people to feel they are being fairly treated, then fairness, equity and equality must be not only perceived but must be a reality in law. The government must accept the principle that these particular amendments will be accepted.
I found it surprising that the whole issue of the merit principle in hiring and promotion would not be perceived as an obligation worthy of promotion by the Public Service sector and by the Treasury Board. The opportunity through review of the employment equity legislation was there and now through this piece of legislation it is again here.
I hope the government will grab this opportunity. As my colleague points out half the employees in the public sector are women but only 15 per cent of managers are women, and that 75 per cent of those who have received promotions have been men and while only half of the employees are men.
The visible minorities and the handicapped are not being promoted in any measurable number. I would say that fair-minded people, men and women, would see that there is justice in this request.
I would like to support my colleague. I would like to ask my colleagues across the floor to be reasonable in looking at Motions Nos. 5 and 7 and to please support them whole-heartedly to provide the full measure of equality, equity, and justice in our society.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to support my colleague from Ottawa West in these two amendments, Motions Nos. 5 and 7.

Before I make a brief statement, I would like to pay tribute to the men and women who render important services to Canadians.

I want to reaffirm my support of the civil service and those many able men and women who render on a daily basis valuable service to Canadians. They are among the finest people with whom I have ever worked. I want to recognize that too often they are the scapegoats of timid, weak, and cowardly politicians.
Oh, oh.

Oui, c'est vrai. Very often they are the scapegoats. You use them and kick them around because you have failed and then they become the target. If you want to debate that I would be delighted to debate it with you. However I suggest that you should not stand up and debate it because you would lose badly.

We talk about pay equity. I think it is an element of basic justice in our Canadian society. We must respect it. We must make every effort to ensure that we have a policy and regulations so that we can act more fairly towards those who are under-represented. When I talk about men and women who are under-represented, I mean native people, visible minorities, and disabled Canadians, whose handicap is often visible. And of course I am talking about women.

If one looks at employment in the Public Service it can be seen that there are a number of under-represented groups. We know that employment is a resource, particularly so today as employment becomes increasingly difficult for a number of Canadians.
June 23, 1992

If we want to continue to build a fair society and a compassionate country then we need to have policies such as those we are discussing today. We need to be sensitive to those who are under-represented.
Therefore, whole-heartedly, without hesitation I support these particular amendments and I would hope that my colleagues would do so as well. They reinforce the merit principle that must be the fundamental building block of our civil service.
Let us not fool ourselves. Many of these people, and I speak about aboriginal people, visible minorities, handicapped Canadians and women, are not getting the jobs that they deserve, not because they do not merit them but because of the deep-seated biases that are within the system. Clearly these amendments would go a long way toward setting those aside.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak on Motions Nos. 5 and 7. As we all know, there are almost a quarter of a million civil servants. These people have studied, some of them at the university level, in order to better serve their fellow citizens, their community, the best community of all: Canada. The Public Service Commission of Canada is the model for civil servants who work for various agencies, companies and firms from coast to coast. That is where the employer should set an example, where it should be a pleasure to serve other Canadians, where we enforce the Canadian legislation. The commission is responsible for the inspection of food and other products so that the community and consumers are protected.
It is vital that the civil servants feel they contribute in no insignificant way to the well-being of this country. They must feel they have their employer's support as well as that of the legislators. They must be happy and feel at home in the Public Service. They should never feel they are being mistreated.
I sincerely hope not one of them will ever be unfortunate enough to work in a group where there is sexual or racial discrimination. I hope that all civil servants, present and future, will always feel equal among their peers and will always know they have equal opportunities in the Public Service so that they may continue to work and advance in their carreers. It must be a question of
Government Orders
equity and justice and not a question of networking among friends.
At the legislative committee, the Liberal Party tabled an amendment to section 5 dealing with employment equity. The original section prepared by government was still seen as a discretionary policy, ill-defined and vague, offering no solution whatsoever for the discrimination problem. The amendment adopted by the committee submits the Treasury Board as an employer to the same obligations as those all Canadian employers must abide by since 1986.
The amendments extend to the Public Service Commission the actual obligations and responsibilities of the Treasury Board in the area of employment equity. They are necessary amendments since the Public Service Commission, and not the Treasury Board, is in charge of recruitment.
That is why, we must allow the Commission to implement employment equity programs.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to congratulate my colleague from the Liberal Party from Ottawa West for her success in getting tremendous movement in this bill in the area of employment equity. I also want to say a few words in support of this amendment and talk about the process that we went through in committee.
First of all, this amendment elaborates on the manner in which Treasury Board and the Public Service Commission would establish employment equity programs.
There has been great reluctance in the past to having employment equity, as applied in the Employment Equity Act, apply to the workers in the public sector. It is one of those laws that applied to others but the government was able to escape its own legislation. Now, with the inclusion of employment equity in this legislation, we feel quite heartened that finally the government is going to take its responsibilities in the area of employment equity seriously.
These two amendments enable the commission to establish affirmative action programs. Affirmative action is one of the fundamental bases for allowing women to take their equal role in the community, to take an equal role in every part of the process of their lives or of Canadian life, including the ability to take full and equal responsibility.

June 23, 1992
Government Orders
Without affirmative action and without employment equity we have had very real barriers to women's participation. When even one person in this country is faced with barriers, either because of physical disability, because of their sex, because of their sexual orientation, because of any of those reasons, then they are made less a Canadian than someone else who is not faced with artificial barriers.
These amendments are another step toward removing those artificial barriers for Canadian workers. They are another step toward showing respect for all workers in the public sector, whether they are men, women, people of colour, people with a physical or mental disability, or whether it is sexual orientation.
We think it is very important that the government acknowledge and respect these areas in the broadest sense, not in the narrowest sense that it can get away with but, in fact, in the broadest sense.
We had an opportunity during the discussion in committee to make additional amendments. We tried very hard to make amendments that would be all-encompassing as opposed limiting, and I have to say that my colleague from Ottawa West was able to make great gains. But the amendments that she is proposing give us the tools to see that those amendments clearly go into action.
We had witnesses for a number of weeks before the committee. It was from a broad range of presenters from the labour movement, from the unions that represent workers in the public sector, from the National Advisory Council on the Status of Women, from the Canadian Ethnocultural Council, and a number of others. They noted very clearly, particularly NAC and the Canadian Ethnocultural Council, the under-representation of women and minorities in our government service. They strongly supported inclusion of strong employment equity provisions in this bill.
This amendment would bring the Public Service Employment Act into line with the federal Employment Equity Act. The Employment Equity Act does not currently include those who work for the federal government, for the people of Canada. In fact, the recommendations tabled recently in the Employment Equity Act included a recommendation that federal government
workers be included under that act. But currently they are not included.
The amendment includes a reporting mechanism for a timetable to be established to achieve employment equity goals. Without some kind of mechanism to measure progress how can we possibly hope to achieve the kinds of things that members on this side of the House are calling for? We need some way to measure the effectiveness of the amendments that are already achieved in the legislation.
I respect the efforts of my colleague from Ottawa West and other members on the opposition side in this committee. But I do want to say that I would very much like to hear from the government side its position other than when we vote some time in the future. I would like to hear articulated by this government what the problem is with this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, it is unfortunate that of all the dissertations made so far on this side of the House in this highest court of the land, we have not heard one come from the government benches yet. That makes one wonder. Maybe it makes those at home wonder. Maybe many of the members of the government, of the Conservative Party, are not knowledgeable on this subject.
That is probably it.

That is probably the point. How many backbenchers can we turn to today, if the only time a backbencher has an opportunity to speak in the House of Commons is just on a Standing Order 31 or in Question Period when we have the media sitting around here and then outside for later comment. Bill C-26 is so flawed that the member for Ottawa West-and I congratulate her for all the work she has done-went through the entire committee process, with the hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester and the hon. member for Mission-Coquitlam clause by clause by clause in this incredible bill. Mr. Speaker, do you know what they came up with? They came up, just at this stage of the bill, with 82 amendments. That is how flawed this bill is.
Because there are certain rules about what you can apply at this particular reading, and that it does not have anything to do with the bill or changes or alters the bill in

some way, the Speaker ruled that a group of amendments just did not cut it, so he dropped them.
Do you know, Mr. Speaker, what that left us to debate? It left us with 30 amendments to debate in this House. How much time do we have to do that? Mr. Speaker, what are we stuck with? We are stuck with a bill that is, as I said, so flawed it has now, and the Chair has accepted, 30 amendments grouped into 19 different piles because some of the amendments are very similar to others.
It is a shame that we have not heard from the government benches opposite. There is much explanation that has to come, a lot of explanation. I am sure that some of the members opposite have experienced in their offices back in their constituencies the same outrage by those employed in the federal civil service that I have had in my office. Representations have come to me in Hamilton West to the office. Civil service unions and their representatives are protesting Bill C-26, a bill for the information of some that amends several pieces of legislation covering the federal government's employment practices.
They have told me, and I am sure they have told the members opposite-even the member from Burlington, I am sure they have even been in his office-that this bill will severely damage the merit principle on which the notion of a professional, non-partisan civil service is based. They have appealed to us. They have said: "It is just not fair. It is not set up to create the programs that we need. It is not fair when we compare our workforce to the private sector workforce. Let us put it all into line here". We have the opportunity to do that but the government does not take that opportunity.
What happens? There is a gentleman by the name John Edwards. He is the official responsible for pushing this PS 2000 through the works. He claims the fears of the representatives of the unions that have come to our offices are exaggerated and unfounded. If the govem-

Mr. Speaker, if I rise to speak about Bill C-26, an act to amend the Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act, which concerns the management of civil servants, it is because Public Service 2000 is perhaps the most important project this House has dealt with in many years. It is very important for us to carry an
in-depth review of the government proposals and I must congratulate the member for Carleton-Gloucester and the member for Ottawa West and at least the entire Liberal caucus for their hard work, a major contribution to the bill, which I think greatly improved this legislation.
The section under review, Motion No 5, which was presented by the member for Ottawa West, is just aiming at transferring responsibilities to the Public Service Commission. We know that thanks to her interventions, the member for Ottawa West managed to do what we had hoped for, what we had been anticipating since 1985, that is to say she forced the federal government as an employer through the Treasury Board which acts as the employer of all civil servants, she forced this employer to abide by the principle of employment equity.
These are amendments that the hon. member for Ottawa West our Liberal Party critic, successfully proposed. A number of amendments that were adopted give Treasury Board in its capacity as an employer the same obligations as any other employer subjected to the legislation, namely to eliminate discriminatory practices regarding employment, and to table each year a report on the progress made, as well as to implement proactive policies and programs to improve job and promotion opportunities for those groups designated in the Employment Equity Act.
One must realize that these provisions did not exist in the original bill. It is an amendment proposed by the Liberal Party that forced the government to assume its responsibilities.
So, this is included in the bill that came back from the committee and that is presently being reviewed at the report stage. What the hon. member for Ottawa West now wants to do is to force the Public Service Commission to implement also an employment equity program that would be equivalent, if you will, to the employer's obligation.
One must understand that there is a distinction to be made between Treasury Board and the Public Service Commission. The latter is a parliamentary organization, an agent of this Parliament which is independent from the government and whose role is to recruit civil servants, to select the best candidate to do the job described by the employer.
June 23, 1992

As for Treasury Board, it identifies the positions that are to be filled, their classification, that is, where those positions fit in the civil service world, as well as the classification standards and the salaries.
The role of the commission is to search for the best candidate to fill a position that has been identified by the employer. As we know, this is done, or at least was done until now, based on the merits of each application.
Since appointments are the responsibility of the Public Service Commission, it seems perfectly normal and fair that the same commission be subjected to strict standards and guidelines regarding recruitment, precisely to avoid any discrimination and to make sure that the provisions of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which all Canadians value, be complied with and that no candidates are rejected because of the colour of their skin or a physical handicap.
Section 15 of our Charter of Rights and Freedoms says, "any program or activity that has as its object the amelioration of conditions of disadvantaged individuals or groups including those that are disadvantaged because of race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability." That is in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
What we want to do with Motions Nos. 5 and 7 before us is to give the Public Service Commission, which selects the best candidate, clear and specific directions in establishing policies and implementing employment equity programs for the designated groups I just mentioned.
I do not think that is so difficult. I think it is very easy and completely logical. The Public Service Commission is responsible for hiring, for selecting the most deserving candidate for a position. We know that the commission has delegated 95 per cent of appointments to departmental managers. Therefore 95 per cent are made by the departments under delegated authority.
The purpose of Public Service 2000 is to give managers more power. I fully agree that they should have more power but their powers should be clear and specific and the House of Commons must give managers directions on our intention to respect employment equity programs.

It is not complicated. That is what Motion No. 5, like Motion No. 7, proposes. They require the Public Service Commission, in selecting the most deserving candidate, to comply with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and section 15 of our Constitution, which forbids discrimination on the basis of race, skin colour and other factors like those I mentioned earlier. I think it is a reasonable amendment; it is not so complicated.
I would just like to close by saying that I am pleased with the improvements that the Liberal Party made to Bill C-26. We will have other equally important amendments to debate. This amendment is clear and precise and I hope that hon. members have understood that it would not take much to accept it.
It would only require the Public Service Commission to implement employment equity programs in all it does-appointments, transfers, training or development-so that the candidates who have access to these programs are chosen without discrimination.

Pay equity means people should be paid the same wages for work of equal value while employment equity means that one must look at ways to promote people of different ethnic backgrounds and different racial backgrounds within our Public Service to ensure our Public Service more accurately reflects the diversity of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I want to speak on this bill today because it has far-reaching implications for the Public Service of Canada. I say that without any partisan view. The merit system in the Public Service has always been the very basis of good administration in this country.
Where the manager in this legislation has been granted excessive authority, he or she can exercise their bias at will. That not only discourages employees on the scene at the time, but it also discourages well qualified personnel going into the Public Service of Canada. That is the serious part of this whole legislation.
We have had great public servants over the years. They have been loyal in their advice and in their attitude to administrations of the day over the years of Canadian history. Their role was to advise ministers, advise the government. When asked to provide bills on certain matters, given the parameters that the government wanted to included in that legislation, in those bills, their job was to provide that information in the various departments concerned.
We have had some outstanding specialists in the Public Service of Canada over the years. That is not going to continue under a system where the managerial ego within individual departments is going to be the order of

the day. Who is going to be favourite of the boss? What are you going to say to your boss? Are you going to tell him that you think that his ideas are bad and that only yours are good? Is there going to be a free flow of information? We have had some great public servants in this country over the years and we have them today, but why are we so gung-ho about passing a bill on Public Service 2000 through this Parliament under closure? This is going to build into that legislation the type of law that is going to give excessive power to the few and discourage great students, talented people, from coming into the Public Service of this nation. It is going to prevent them from coming into the Public Service when Canada needs some of the greatest advice, the greatest base of accurate assessment of information we have ever needed in years.
The merit system is indeed the raison d'etre, the reason for being, the reason for outstanding people coming into the Public Service of Canada.
The merit system promotes greater depth in the advice, in the accuracy and in the informed knowledge that will be passed on to this government and future governments in Canada.

Pursuant to Standing Order 76(8), the recorded division on the motion stands deferred.

We shall now proceed to the consideration of Motions Nos. 9, 11 and 13, all standing in the name of the hon. member for Ottawa West.

Motion No. 9.
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 8 by striking out lines 20 to 22 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"7.1 (1) The Commission may conduct investigations and audits on any matter within its jurisdiction.
(2) The Commission shall investigate complaints filed by employees alleging sexual or personal harassment or abuse of authority and shall report its findings and the corrective action taken under section 7.5, if any, to the employee who filed the complaint." Motion No. 11.
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 8 by striking out line 33 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"or person employed with the Commission."
Motion No. 13.
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 8 by striking out line 11 at page 5 and substituting the following therefor:
"sion shall, on the basis of any investigation,".
She said: Mr. Speaker, since the government has clearly indicated its intention to reject Motions Nos. 5 and 7 on employment equity, Motion No. 9 becomes even more important, because it is an amendment that ensures the Public Service Commission has the authority and the responsibility for investigating complaints of sexual or personal harassment or abuse of authority filed by public servants.
It is even more important, since the government is not prepared to give the Public Service Commission, on behalf of Parliament, any responsibility in the matter of employment equity that these three motions which touch directly on the accountability of managers and an impartial method of ensuring that they do not abuse the new authority that this bill gives them, to have these safeguards in this bill.
The question of accountability was one thread throughout our debate in committee and is a thread throughout this bill. It is worth quoting from the minutes of a couple of meetings because throughout appearances by the minister and by senior officials I repeatedly asked them to show me where in this bill is the increased accountability that the minister and Mr. Edwards, responsible for PS 2000, have told Parliament, have told Public Service employees and have told the public is there. Tell those who rely on this Public Service for fair and impartial treatment on the front lines, in unemployment insurance offices, in getting their welfare cheques or their old age security cheques. Tell us where in this bill is the increased accountability.
Not once in three months of hearings was one senior manager or the minister or the parliamentary secretary able to point to one clause in this bill that clearly increases accountability.
We support the need for reform in the Public Service. We understand that people have to be given the responsibility and the freedom to be creative, to make decisions, to take risks, to manage well, but we also understand that increased freedom, whether for a citizen, for a child or for a manager means increased accountability for actions. It means checks and balances to ensure that increased power is not abused at the expense of others who are less able to defend themselves.
June 23, 1992



I would like to refer to several issues of the proceedings of the legislative committee where we had these discussions and where I asked a number of questions, lake the report of the task force on barriers to women in the Public Service, for instance. In its report Beneath the Veneer, the task force said that attitudes were the main obstacle to the advancement and equal treatment of women in the Public Service.
In other words, the merit principle has never been applied fairly to women. I put a question to the President of the Treasury Board, and I said that they talked about increased accountability but I found no trace of it in this bill. I asked about this increased accountability of managers to Parliament, to the government, that would ensure the Government of Canada was not governed by favouritism and nepotism. I received no specific reply on the clause of the bill that deals directly with increased accountability.

At the end of the minister's answer I had to say that I asked specifically: "Where in this bill is increased accountability contained?" and made the point that I had not heard that answer from the minister.

I put the same question to Mr. Edwards, and I said that since we were giving managers more freedom and greater latitude and possibilities for filing an appeal or reviewing management decisions were being reduced, had they considered provisions that would enhance accountability, as a counterweight to this greater freedom? Mr. Edwards answered that in their opinion it was clear that the provisions of the bill contained certain legal requirements.

Mr. Edwards, as well as the minister and Mr. Robert Lafleur, deputy secretary, Human Resources Development Branch, Treasury Board Secretariat, were not able to point out one sentence in this bill that increases accountability.

I attended hearings conducted by the Public Service Alliance and I attended meetings with Public Service employees during the development of PS 2000. I heard again and again from women and visible minorities that they do not get paid the same, they do not get treated the same, and they do not get the same opportunities for promotion. They never get beyond that glass ceiling. They are desperately afraid that with new powers it is going to become even more important whether their manager likes them and whether they are the kind of person he or she thinks deserves to progress in the Public Service.
Women particularly, but also those who are disabled and aboriginal Canadians, have expressed fears about both sexual and personal harassment and about attitudes that have nothing to do with their ability to do their work affecting their ability to progress.
This motion is an attempt to ensure that the commission, which is accountable to Parliament, not to the government but to Parliament, has fair employment practices. It asks that the commission has the responsibility and the power to investigate complaints of harassment and abuse of authority.
We as parliamentarians need that safeguard. I do not expect that every manager, most managers, or even a large number of managers are suddenly going to become raving power maniacs wielding whips over people in the Public Service. However we write laws for those whose own moral principles do not guide proper behaviour. We already have very good documentation that attitudes do not allow people to be considered only on their merits.
Taken together these amendments are very clear. Their purpose is to ensure that there is redress, there is accountability, and there are checks and balances against the new powers that managers are given by this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to lend my support to these particular motions. We have dealt with Motions Nos. 5 and 7 and they will be voted on in the future.
Now we deal with Motions Nos. 9,11 and 13. They are being grouped for debate. As we have heard so eloquently said by the member for Ottawa West, we are dealing with these particular motions on sexual harassment, personal harassment, or abuse of authority.

If anyone out there believes that we do not need to tighten the bill because the reality of today is that there is a change in society, men are more understanding of women and men accept the fact that women are equals, we cannot believe that. We cannot believe that is what is being felt by all men. That is just not the case.
I am part of a generation, one of the later baby boomers I suppose, that says: "We accept this as a reality. I am not challenged or feel challenged by a woman of equal or more powerful stature or responsibility than I".
There are men who are threatened. We do not have to go too far to bump into these individuals. We do not have to go too far out of this place to hear what goes on in private conversations between men when they cloister and have a few laughs. It is a shameful display but it is a reality.
That is why we want something in this particular bill that recognizes that fact. That is why on Motion No. 9 my colleague from Ottawa West explained that the commission does at present conduct investigations on complaints of harassment or abuse of authority. We recognize that it goes on. However, there is no clear mandate in the legislation for it to do so.
What is the point then? We are missing something. There is a piece of that puzzle, of that picture that is missing. The picture is not complete. That is what this motion attempts to do.
Since we all admit here today that harassment can be and is a clear interference with the merit principle this subclause clearly spells out the right of the commission to investigate such complaints.
As well, the increased authority of managers creates the concern that some managers may misuse their new control over employees and their career opportunities within the Public Service to the particular disadvantage of women and visible minorities. To believe otherwise is living in a fool's paradise. That is quite clear.
My hon. colleague for Ottawa West speaks of a glass ceiling. I am not so sure it is glass. I think it is a concrete ceiling. Maybe it is a rubber ceiling because when women and minorities hit it they bounce right down. They bounce right down because the opportunity that is
afforded to them to advance is there but we all know that in many cases it just does not happen for them.
In this package we are also dealing with Motion No. 11, which deals with the delegation of authority to deputy heads when we are talking about audits and investigations. As the member for Ottawa West has already mentioned the common thread that is running through the entire debate, which went on not only at the three months of committee meetings that she and the member for Carleton-Gloucester attended, is the whole issue of attitude by individuals.
I had representation in my constituency office from those who are part of the Public Service unions. They were concerned that the commission could delegate to or allow investigations and audits to be conducted by deputy heads. Motion No. 11 will ensure that these investigations or audits are conducted impartially by someone under the direct control of the commission and independent of the departments.
It is especially important, given the extended authority of deputy heads, that investigations or audits be carried out at arm's length.
Also in this group of amendments, which we will seek the government to respond to in some way or say: "Yes, maybe we ought to have another look at that and maybe yes, we will accept that particular amendment", is Motion No. 13.
The purpose of this motion is to ensure that where an investigation audit or report indicates that corrective measures are necessary the commission shall take corrective action. In Bill C-26 it says "may take corrective action". We say "shall take corrective action". The clause still leaves it to the discretion of the commission to determine what corrective action is appropriate.
We are dealing with three motions at this particular time, Nos. 9, 11 and 13. These amendments to the bill have become very crucial by all indications. For the last hour and 15 minutes or so that we discussed Motions Nos. 5 and 7 not a single member got up in the House to debate those particular motions and answer our concerns directly. That is a shameful attitude on behalf of the government.
Couple that with the fact that we now have this jackboot tactic of closure and we are only allowed to speak for four hours on all 30 amendments put forward

It takes me back to last night and the debate on the immigration bill. We had one day. We were talking about reform, the largest of any kind on immigration ever done since 1978. Today we are dealing with the Public Service and we are allowed four hours. This is an abuse of Parliament.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to speak to these particular amendments, Motions Nos. 9, 10 and 11. It is a good idea to read what is actually in these motions, particularly Motion No. 9. In clause 7.1 it says that the commission "may" conduct investigations and audits. The key part of the amendment that has been put forward by this side is:
(2) The commission shall investigate complaints filed by employees alleging sexual or personal harassment or abuse of authority and shall report its findings and the corrective action taken under section 7.5, if any, to the employee who filed the complaint.
The motion gets to the heart of the issue of protecting employees and giving them the confidence of feeling that they are part of a system that will support them rather than be against them and that they have the method of redress essential to this type of system.
We have to be mindful that the system is there to protect. The motion adds the additional protection of not having to work through the system but through the commission that reports to Parliament and tells us what is going on.
The concern I have, and I am sure others have as well, is that there is a trend away from Parliament. We saw a trend with the immigration bill last night to have things handled by regulation rather than by legislation in Parliament. We saw the use of closure in Parliament both on this bill and on the immigration bill. We only had one day to deal with the immigration bill. Now we have only four hours to deal with these very complicated and complex amendments, which were designed and offered in goodwill to improve legislation that has some flaws and problems.
We on this side of the House understand that reform is necessary and that reform dealing with the Public Service is an essential element. We want to work with the government to see that it is achieved.
However, you tend to lose your compassion and your desire to work with this government when you see the tactics that are being utilized to force this through.
It is the same thing, quite frankly, on a different topic. It ties in with Bill C-55 in dealing with pensions. The government adopted that legislation in an arbitrary way. It changed rates of contribution and established interest rates which were retroactive to the previous year. They may take away indexation and make changes to the plans that are in place and at their beck and call without Parliament or the people being fully consulted. We are again running into this type of situation with Bill C-26.
I think we all have to realize and understand that if we are going to have a civil service or a Public Service that functions properly then there has to be mutual respect and a system that will give these employees an opportunity to flourish and to achieve their goals and objectives as individuals.
Charlotte Gray in a recent Saturday Night article states: "Without the federal government to lubricate the wheels of Confederation, run airports, impose national standards, collect taxes and regulate phones, trade, and television stations, Canada might be even closer to disintegration".
We have to be mindful of what is involved with the Public Service. I think that when we do have these massive walk outs and wildcat strikes we do see some of the ramifications and we feel them for a short period of time. However, we do tend to forget all of the things that are done by our civil service which help hold this country together and provide the nuts, bolts, and glue to make the system work.
I will quote another portion of that same article by Charlotte Gray. It really drives home the point of the frustration and the concern and why we need Motions Nos. 9, 10 and 11. It is to put into the system those protections. I quote: "One layer below, morale among managers spirals downward because of the contraction of the Public Service". It now constitutes 1.7 per cent of the Canadian labour force compared with 2.4 per cent in 1974. "Promotion prospects have dried up. 'We are treated like light bulbs,' moans one 45 year-old who works a 60-hour week and whose career is going no-

where. The guys at the top assume there are always new ones to replace those of us who bum out'."
I think that typifies the feeling that a lot of public servants have to what is happening to them. They of course feel that there is no mechanism for them to redress those concerns. There is no mechanism that will respond to their concerns.
We on this side feel that by strengthening clause 8, and in particular with Motions Nos. 9, 11 and 13, that mechanism will be strengthened to such an extent that people will not feel they are light bulbs who are just there to bum out and be discarded. Instead, they will feel that they are an integral part of a system that appreciates what they do, encourages them in what they do, and encourages them to seek the highest possible attainment of on-the-job satisfaction and the pride in doing a job and doing it well.
We have seen the politicization of the Public Service over the last number of years and I think that is a cause of great concern and another area in which the Public Service feels they have been put into the background and are not a contributor to the process.
I think they have been made to feel as scapegoats in the political agenda of this government. We need the strengthening of these sections and improvements in the bill over all. As we are dealing with these motions, we need some improvements in them to improve the power of the commission to protect the Public Service.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak on the issues before us today that deal with a number of principles involving employment in the public sector. The first interesting observation was of course the previous member speaking about the horrors of closure and phrases such as the application by the Conservative government of jackboot measures and other rather sedate and calm language. I remember in the House of Commons when the hon. member's party was in government we pretty well had a closure bill amended here during that period of time. To hear the Liberal Party stand up and justify the necessity of using jackboot measures and closure surprises me. It is kind of ironic to see the jackboots on the other feet for the time being.
I am sure that as the next election plays out we will likely see closure being applied the other way. Maybe we should just find a better way of doing it rather than going through this hypocrisy.
The interesting thing about the principles of the bill-and I do support the amendments that have been brought forward-is the question of equity in the work place and the protection of employees from arbitrary and illegal use of the power of position. On those two bases, I think there is an extremely important point to be made.
One of them is on pay equity. I had an interesting opportunity with the leader of the Liberal Party of British Columbia. I admit that the individual is somewhat of a novice, but it would be interesting to see the federal Liberal Party and the provincial Liberal parties singing from the same song sheet. The song sheet that the provincial leader of the Liberal Party of British Columbia was singing from basically said that we are in a recession. The economy will not permit a government to pursue pay equity for women.
Rephrasing that, the Liberal Party of British Columbia is saying the same thing that the Conservative Party is saying. Speaking on pay equity, society, and the Conservatives and the Liberals as parties, say that in order to retain the privileged position of men, women have to stay in the job ghettos. They have got to take the pay ghetto, as it were, in order that men can maintain that privileged position. It is an unfortunate thing for the leader of a political party to make such a statement. It was done on television and it was absolutely untenable.
What should happen is that federal colleagues who are advocating the position of pay equity against a government that seems not inclined to recognize how important this issue is should be looking clearly at giving a signal to their provincial colleagues that maybe they should be singing from the same song sheet if they want British Columbians and Canadians to believe what they are saying.
It is almost the same position as they are in with the closure issue. Let us come up with a new approach so as not to look so hypocritical to someone who is watching the Liberals in government and then watching them, or the Conservatives for that matter, in opposition.

The next question is whether pay equity is a right for human beings. That means equal pay for work of equal value. It must be recognized and dealt with.
The next important issue again deals with the whole question of harassment. It could be harassment of any type against men or women in the work place where one individual with power over another exercises that power in an inappropriate or illegal manner. Again women have borne the brunt of the harassment in the work place. The amendments before us today ask that that the government consider putting in place effective measures to reduce and eliminate harassment in the workplace.
I think the key point here is that the Government of Canada should set an example. The Government of Canada should not be the worst employer in Canada. It should be looking to be a model to signal other employers that this is what our expectation is. It could be changing the attitudes of employers by moral suasion and example rather than legislation. The government really has not seemed to be inclined to do that.
If we look at the Canada Post Corporation, it is probably one of the worst employers in Canada. There are Neanderthal practices within that corporation absolutely beyond a doubt.
Maybe one could say that in a perverse manner it is setting an example for employers in Canada of what not to do as an employer. The practices within that corporation are absolutely disgusting.
As the owner the Government of Canada should be looking at ways of making that corporation a model in terms of employer-employee practices.
Here is another example that is absolutely critical. If one is going to signal other employers in Canada, then one should be making the agencies of the Government of Canada a model. The Government of Canada, with the Conservative Party in power, should be making its agencies examples of what other employers should be doing and not examples of what they should not be doing.
It would be an incredibly good opportunity to bring employment practices into the 20th century or on into the 21st century in the Armed Forces. If you look at the Armed Forces as an employer it is an incredible organization. Here is an example. When I represented an area

in which the Armed Forces were involved an incredible issue would result where an individual would run into grief. They would go after tremendous frustration to their member of Parliament because they were suppressed by the officers. They were warned: "You do not go outside this system or we will get you no matter what happens".
Eventually they would go outside the system and go to a member of Parliament. The issue would then be adjudicated to some degree in the public eye, the individual would be transferred and, after a few years, he would indeed be driven out or he would be penalized to an enormous degree. If one breaks the chain of command then one is in serious difficulty.
It is time the Armed Forces in Canada had an effective union. In Europe there are countries with unionized armed forces. This country, in terms of its employment practices within the Government of Canada, is absolutely in the Dark Ages. We watched examples of arbitrary practices in there. Somebody is overweight. They decide to throw them out of the Armed Forces but the officer who makes that decision is overweight. Out they go. They put in a grievance. It takes two years for the grievance to be processed. The individual has been in total chaos and the grievance process in there is terribly ineffective.
In one case it eventually wound up where the cabinet had to consider the most dishonest practice that would ever have been considered in any public sector or any private sector of employment. The laws of Canada would have prohibited what went on inside the Armed Forces.
Shame.

The individual was eventually reinstated by a decision of cabinet. They would not tolerate inside the Armed Forces any remediation of a terribly abusive order. That started on the ground floor. It is amazing. The officer who inflicted the order in that case was promoted and now sits in Ottawa today in a promoted position which took two years of enormous conflict within the Armed Forces.
In there goes sexual harassment and harassment of employees where a tremendous abuse of power occurs and there is no effective remediation. We are going into the 21st century. It is time that this Government of Canada dealt with its Public Service, an honourable,

dedicated, committed organization, in a fair and equitable way. It should use the employer-employee relationship to set a prime, key example for other employers in Canada. It should not set an example of what you should not do or an example of employment practices of the last century.
I view the amendments put forward by my colleague as constructive and worthy of support, making the Public Service of Canada and the Government of Canada an example of good, solid future-looking employer-employee relations.

Mr. Speaker, this is a very important bill. That is why the hon. member for Mississauga should get up and give us a very inspiring speech as he knows how to do.
I am willing to give my time to the member for Mississauga if he would get up and give us his views on this very important matter. I know how he feels. He is a fair individual and a fair person. He is a man of great, great principle. He is a man who understands. All we are trying to do here, with these three amendments, Motions Nos. 9, 11 and 13, is to give a clear mandate to the commission in the legislation for it to do these investigations on complaints of harassment and abuse of authority.
One does not have to be a genius nor a legislator of great experience to understand this is a fundamental right of individuals, to know what is going on and to know that they will be informed of investigations and will have a right to comment on them.
As we know, the commission at this time does these investigations. We are trying, with these amendments, to make it clear that harassment per se could be an interference with the merit principle. We would like the commission to be empowered by legislation to do these inquiries and to do them in an open manner and to do them with the follow-up that is required of these investigations.
All we are asking is that the commission do the investigations, not somebody from the department where the individual works, not somebody from outside government, but somebody within the powers of the commission to appoint within that commission so that we make sure that is protected in the law.
The first amendment says that the commission must do those investigations and audits on any matter within
its jurisdiction and investigate complaints filed by employees alleging sexual and personal harassment.
I had a case this morning of harassment of a public servant by a superior. This individual works in national defence and his wife is very sick. He missed a few days because of his wife's illness. When he came back to work and told his supervisor that he was absent for the last seven or eight days because of his wife's illness, the supervisor refused to accept the medical certificate. He refused to accept the word of the individual and his medical doctor attesting to the fact that he was justifiably absent from work.
This is the second time this has happened. The last time this member of the Public Service was off work, every day at 7 a.m., at 10 a.m., at noon, in the afternoon and in the evening the supervisor would call to make sure that the individual was home looking after his wife. Getting seven or eight phone calls a day from your boss trying to verify that you are looking after your sick wife becomes quite tiresome.
Harassment.

That is what we call harassment. That is exactly what we are trying to do here. An employee who is harassed that way should have a right, if there is a complaint lodged by the employee as to a supervisor harassing him or her, to say to the commission: "Investigate this problem. Find out why this person is harassing me and for God's sake, let us stop that nonsense". That is all this does. It gives the commission the authority to do not as it so feels about it, not as clause 8 says: "The commission may-". We want the word "shall", not "may". We are trying to replace the word "may" within the legislation before us with the word "shall". The commission shall investigate, not may investigate.
The other point we are trying to make with Motion No. 11 is that the unions have expressed concerns to us that to delegate this authority to investigate or audit to deputy heads of the department could be a conflict of interest within the department.
That point is very easy to understand. We are telling managers that by Public Service 2000 we will give them more powers to manage. That was not anything new. It was said in many royal commissions before: Give the managers power to manage and pay them accordingly. That is why managers are paid more than the average worker. It is because they manage a department. They have responsibilities and judgment calls to make.
June 23, 1992

In Public Service 2000 we have a different tack now. Not only are managers going to be paid to manage, but we are also going to give them a carrot. We are going to give them something else and that is more authority. Well, that authority must be controlled.
With these amendments, all we are saying is that people in the departments have a right to and should be entitled to equal rights. All we are asking is that the House adopt the three amendments that would make investigations and audits of the commission an in-house Public Service Commission obligation. A follow-up must be done and as much as possible it must be done by somebody not within the department, not within that section of the government where the person works.
These amendments are not very difficult and I recommend them to the attention of the House.

On these amendments dealing with auditing within the department concerned or where the complaint comes from, that procedure would be a very simple one because we have a situation here where unions express concern that the commission could delegate to or allow investigations and audits to be conducted by deputy heads.
I have just gone through some of my public accounts papers when I chaired the Standing Committee on Public Accounts for three years. Oddly enough, I found in there that we are supporting the Auditor General of Canada in having a greater control over the internal operations of departments and that is the role that any public accounts committee in this House should be playing. My colleague from Ottawa-Vanier is now chairing that committee and I am sure he would agree with me very strongly that is precisely what should take place.
Instead of bringing in a bill that is going to delegate these duties, instead of tightening up the system, where are we going to get the strong financial control in the Government of Canada? It is not only in big contracts or big deals that money sometimes is lost, but it is also all the dribbling away here and there down through the system. That is where the tax dollars are lost.
I support the Auditor General in his desire to have absolute tight control within departments. I support the
Government Orders
suggestion of my colleague from Ottawa West who brought in Motion No. 11 which specifically mentions the term "investigations and audits" which the commission might wish to delegate to other department heads.
So let us not throw the baby out with the bath water. We have had some good systems in place before which have served the country well. In passing any legislation in this House we must support the Auditor General of Canada because he is the one the public of this country looks to, to make sure that he is bringing out the wrongdoings in government, the leakages and wasted tax dollars in government, and to try to tighten up the system and give the Canadian people some value for their dollars.
In relation to Motions Nos. 9,11 and 13, they deal with some very serious matters. Harassment is mentioned here. My hon. friend from Ottawa-Vanier mentioned one case this morning. You are going to run into some very good managers in the Public Service of Canada, but you are also going to run into some managers who cannot handle a little bit of authority. Calling somebody's home six, seven, or eight times a day I would say is a pretty good case of paranoia. These people should not be in positions of authority.
How can anybody say that by passing this legislation today we are going to increase the efficiency of the Public Service of Canada? Is that manager or his delegate getting paid on a salary or at hourly rate to pick up the phone every once in awhile to phone somebody's home like a little Gestapo agency? Why do we pay people to do those things? Is there no trust left in the system at all? If a boss cannot trust his employees, why should the employees trust the boss? That is where management comes into this system.
I want to read something relating to procedures outlined in these three amendments in a very general way. It is a report I tabled in this House on November 8, 1990, when I was chairing the public accounts committee.
Part A says: "Your committee recommends that the government give consideration to tabling a discussion paper prior to proceeding with the introduction of legislative amendments and/or administrative changes and that this discussion paper set out the principal conclusions and recommendations arising from Public Service 2000". That covers the type of details we are talking about here.
